reviewText: The characters remain the same; the flavor of the show changes though. This season has lost some of the humor, replacing it with grit and some amazing cinematography. They really caught the desert light, which was something missing from previous seasons. And while I love how beautiful the scenes were this season, I *liked* the humor and the lightness of the previous seasons. It seemed to regain some of this later on in the season, so I'm guessing they had others who were able to review while it was still being aired who felt the same.All in all, I liked it as much as previous seasons - just for different reasons.
summary: A little different from previous seasons

reviewText: One of the the best and most popular dramas on TV, CSI is often intense and chilling. The scenes showing the laboratory work are fascinating.  Excellent portrayal of team dynamics with people alternately working together and competing against each other.Here is an episode guide, with a tiny description:1. Assume Nothing (Part 1):  After two couples meet in a bar, one couple is killed.  When it happens again, the CSI team suspects serial killers.2. All for Our Country (Part 2):  The lead suspects are killed and Grissom suspects it may have been a cop.3. Homebodies:  An old woman is found mummified.  A teen is raped.4. Feeling the Heat:  A triple digit heat wave brings cases of a baby locked in a car, heat stroke, and a woman floating in a lake.5. Fur and Loathing:  A man is found dead dressed in a raccoon suit.  A gunshot victim is found frozen in a deep-freezer.6. Jackpot:  A severed head is shipped to Dr. Robbins. Grissom goes to look for the body.7. Invisible Evidence:  At a preliminary hearing for a rape-murder case, the evidence is thrown out on a technicality.8. After the Show:  Catherine takes over a high profile case because the suspect is infatuated with her.9. Grissom Versus the Volcano:  Political pressure influences a sheriff trying to find who killed an air marshall with a car bomb.10. Coming of Rage:  A teenager is found murdered on a construction site.11. Eleven Angry Jurors:  The lone holdout on a jury is found dead in the jury room.12. Butterflied:  A woman who resembles Sara is found murdered.  Grissom takes an interest in the case.  Rated TV-14-SV.13. Suckers:  An electrocution is a coverup for a theft from an exhibit of Japanese antiquities.14. Paper or Plastic:  A shootout during a grocery store robbery results in five deaths.15. Early Rollout:  A porn star and her husband are murdered execution style.16 . Getting Off:  A man wearing make-up is murdered.  At first he appears to have been a transvestite, then the CSI team discovers that he was a clown.17. XX:  A bus carrying inmates from a women's prison is discovered to have a dead body underneath the bus.18. Bad to the Bone:  A murder in a parking garage and an episode at the police station leads to a series of shocking discoveries in a case involving a dead body and a missing woman and child.19. Bad Words:  A competitor in a word game tournament is found dead with letter tiles in his stomach.20. Dead Ringer:  CSI investigate a runner's death that occurred during a competition.  A couple is killed in a hotel room during a cop competition.21. Turning the Screws:  A roller coaster runs off track leaving 6 people dead.  (The roller coaster is actually in Pharaoh's Lost Kingdom in Redlands, California.)22. No More Bets:  Two men who scammed Sam Braun's casinos are murdered.23. Bloodlines:  A DNA test sets a man free that a victim has identified as having raped her.
summary: C.S.I. Crime Scene Investigation - The Complete 4th Season

reviewText: A wonderfully-produced TV show with incredible performances by William Petersen. Often chilling, what with dead babies, a rat coming out of a victim's mouth, limbs all over the place, guts galore..quite realistic. And don't watch this show with former or current Police Officers; they always laugh at many of the hokey solutions and all of the forensic geniuses. ("l see a drop of blood on the 3rd button of your vest.lt obviously came from someone standing very close to you. What's that? Your son had a bloody nose?")But the most jarring note in the episodes is the constant references to Marg Helgenberger as a "very beautiful" former exotic dancer - and "gorgeous" and "lovely". Yet not only does she act and walk more like a former streetwalker with her tight and low-cut clothing, she is just not at all pretty, simply your run-of-the-mill aging actress. The vast majority of viewers l've come across all agree on this point, the question being:"Is she married to one of the studio execs?"

reviewText: "Whooooo are yo-ou o-ou?"  The best theme song of any show on TV is topped only by the actual quality of the show.  Season 4 picks up just where season 3 left off, and doesn't miss a beat in terms of show or acting quality.  Every episode of this show has me glued to the screen, and it doesn't stop here either, I can't wait for season 5.This show remains one of the top couple shows in the ratings, and has brought about a huge new interest in forensic science.  Colleges across the country are starting new criminal science programs or increasing their existing ones.  This show is not only incredibly interesting, but is also making an actual difference in the world.  There are few shoes on TV today that can say that.William Petersen's acting is simply brilliant as Gil Grissim, and with marvolous support from actors and actresses like Marg Helgenberger (Catherine Willows), George Eads (Nick Stokes), Gary Dourdan (Warrick Brown), Jorja Fox (Sara Sidle), Paul Guilfoyle (Captain Jim Brass), and Eric Szmanda (Greg Sanders), the show can't (and doesn't in any way) miss.  Do yourself a huge favor and pick it up today.  It's a little pricey, but it's really worth every cent.

reviewText: By the time "CSI" hit season four, the show had been on top of the ratings for a few years. It would be understandable for it to slip off the pedestal it had been placed upon. But it didn't - season four of television's #1 crime drama was as captivating as ever.Season four picks up where season three left off; nightshift supervisor Gil Grissom (William Petersen) is back from his ear surgery and has a renewed sense of purpose in his work. Catherine Willows (Marg Helgenberger) has found a personal life after the death of her ex-husband, while Nick Stokes (George Eads) finds himself up against a co-worker for a promotion - and graciously deals with the competition. Warrick Brown (Gary Dourdan) is the consummate professional when his work is questioned in the courtroom, and Sara Sidle (Jorja Fox) continues her downward spiral after Grissom rejects her both personally and professionally.As the characters continued to grow and develop during season four, the cases became more intriguing as well. Granted, there were some bizarre ones - one needs to look no further than 'Fur and Loating' for a truly strange case - but many of them were simply well-done. The season two-part opener deals with a local couple who targets tourists, while 'Paper or Plastic' is about a grocery store robbery. Other highlights include 'Invisible Evidence', where the crime lab is against the clock in prosecuting a murderer, 'Bloodlines', a case about a raped woman who has seemingly misidentified her attacker in a police lineup, and 'Turn of the Screws', which revolves around an accident at an amusement park. The best episode of the season - and perhaps the best of the show thus far - is undoubtedly 'Butterflied', in which a woman who bears an uncanny resemblance to Sara is found murdered. It is truly a psychological thriller that will have you on the edge of your seat.Murder? Check. Unusual cases? Check. Intriguing character development? Check. Season four of "CSI" once again has all the ingredients to entertain you - again and again.
Title: N/A

reviewText: They included commentary on the season premiere ASSUME NOTHING, but nothing on ALL FOR OUR COUNTRY which was the resolution. So all of disc 1 should have had commentary. Jerry Stahl AGAIN gets screwed over & this was him comeback episode. Stahl had written nothing for Season 3, no work after the Season 2 finale THE HUNGER ARTIST. Stahl returned with a vengeance with FUR & LOATHING IN LAS VEGAS. Stahl outdid himself with the plushies, people who get their greatest sexual satisfaction wearing animal costumes. 1-liner after 1-liner after 1-liner. With the ratings & water-cooler gossip the next day made it a classic. Even the B-Plot of that murder victim was memorable for the fact he was frozen to the floor & that far back was a rare moment of Robbins in the field.Following the tradition of the ripped from the headlines episodes that came before it-UNFRIENDLY SKIES(1) & ANATOMY OF A LYE(2), AFTER THE SHOW would get the brushoff. Based on the murder of LA cheerleader Linda S0bek, AFTER THE SHOW focused on the murder of a model just beginning her career only to have her promise snuffed out by her creepy photographer. So all of disc 2 should have had commentary.The confrontation between Grissom & officer Charles Fromansky was ushered in ALL FOR OUR COUNTRY, that followed in PAPER OR PLASTIC? which had the team dealing with mass murder at a grocery store. Jamie Allman turned in quite the turn as Celeste Turner, the employee who organizes the robbery because her boss keeps her hours too low to qualify for benefits.EARLY R0LL0UT which was the last episode to have writing form Creator Anthony Zuiker as he would shift to his role as Showrunner on C.S.I. NEW YORK, had character development for Catherine as it introduced Nicolas Lea as nightclub owner Cris Besich. Their pairing would carry on for the remainder of the season. EARLY R0LL0UT also hinted at Sara's substance abuse.Jerry Stahl got the shaft a second time. GETTING OFF was insane, a woman who could only get her rocks off by having sex with men made up as clowns, the B-Plot of the drug khat which was a reference to Bruckheimer's war epic BLACK HAWK DOWN which costarred Kim COates who played Drake Snow in EARLY R0LL0UT. Extensive location filming in Las Vegas with the teaser getting off with a nice shot of the Stratosphere Tower.DEAD RINGER was the last episode written by technical advisor Elizabeth Devine who decided to leave C.S.I. to become a full-time writer on C.S.I. MIAMI. DEAD RINGER involved multiple jurisdictions as featuring the law enforcement relay race.NO MORE BETS, furthered the Catherine/Besich romance as well as Catherine having to deal with Sam Braun again as a murder suspect but now she was unable to work any case related to Braun because in the Season 3 finale INSIDE THE BOX, we learned, she learned Braun was her father. Grissom had to question Catherine's objectivity when he learned of the 250000 dollar check Braun ,ailed to her in JACKPOT.Now we get to season finale BLOODLINES which ran out from left field in it dealt with a rapist getting away with it even though the victim, pit boss Linley Parker clearly identifies psychologist Todd Coombs. Parker is later found dead & the DNA has a filial connection to Coombs so the team collects DNA from all of the Coombs' men. No match from any of the brothers & we get the big reveal, it was at the same time, Coombs & his twin brother whose DNA was absorbed by Coombs, a twin that never developed. What allowed Coombs to beat DNA testing was the genetic quirk of chimerism, when a zygote fails to develop & the DNA is absorbed by the surviving twin. So the DNA of the stomach does not match the DNA of the liver, different DNA between lungs & kidneys. Chimerism has been a real life news story where people had to fight overwhelming odds to prove innocence of crimes, prove maternity or paternity. Chimerism is still quite the medical mystery. The producers could have called in the leading doctor in the country who specializes in chimerism research to provide commentary. Also commentary from guest stars George Newbern & Nina Siemaszko who each turned in brilliant, unforgettable performances.So many times when the show does something special like this, it gets little to no focus on the DVD. It's disgraceful how much of Season 4 went unrecognized on the DVD.
summary: YOU CAN CORRECTLY ASSUME WE WILL GET NOTHING

reviewText: Ignore the spinoffs and immerse yourself in the best crime drama on DVD, CSI: CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATION. Not one to conform to usual TV laws of diminishing returns, CSI has kept its quality and realism intact, while providing a sold night's veiwing. Outshining shows like Criminal Intent and NYCS, this has been one omy favourites and  still remains as sharp and potent as it was when originally aired. Especially impressive since this has the possibility to become a very repetitive show, but thankfully the writers have kept it real without sacrificing any sense of entertainment. Keep it up, the characters (Especially Grissom) are always compelling, the stories are fresh and the music rocks.  This is essential Television on the silver disc.

reviewText: CSI Season 4 disappoints in comparison to Seasons 1-3.In its first three years, CSI felt fresh with its terrific ensemble cast, excellent writing, brilliant structure and movie-caliber production values.  Episodes about subjects like a dead scuba diver in a tree and a crazed passenger in first-class were truly inspired.In Season 4, unfortunately, something gives.  Maybe the writers came up with these over-the-top, ludicrous stories with shallow character development because they were running out of ideas.  Maybe the producers felt more explosions and soap opera "office politics" would keep viewers happy.In any event, there is a noticeable drop-off in quality - especially in the writing - and overall Season 4 feels like one of those sequels where the creative talent is more interested in cashing in than discovering new ways to evolve the show.  Think "Star Wars" after the first two sequels.In Seasons 1-3, "CSI" could also stand for clever, subtle and intelligent.  In Season 4, though, the acronym changes to contrived, self-satisfied and imitative.  CSI is still an OK show in Season 4, but it's sad when such an original and enjoyable series regresses to the mean of network TV mediocrity (i.e., Explosions! Grisly violence!  Sex!  More explosions!).CSI used to achieve an exquisite balance of plot, characterization, science, cinematography and music.  Season 4 turns away from those strengths to showcase fireballs and bad guys in ski masks, and consequently is only a shadow of its former self - the well-written, inspired drama that happened to be on network TV.
summary: CSI Season 4 Missing Creative Spark of Prior Seasons

reviewText: In its fourth season, CSI focuses more on the crimes and their participants, although the regular cast does have some momentous moments:  Grissom's surgery results; his involvement or lack of with Sarah, who starts manifesting her own personal crisis; and Catherine finds a new beau and a new paternal figure.  As always, the series is ripe with intriguing plots, forensic facts, and crisp writing, editing and performances.  Jorja Fox and Eric Szmanda continue to grow in their roles while Petersen, Helgenberger and Guilfoyle continue to provide the foundation of excellence for this always enjoyable series.  On to Season 5!

reviewText: I'm sorry, but I'm unable to rate the fourth season of CSI favorably.  Although the first three seasons were fresh and interesting, the fourth one starts to lag.  I have found some of the predictable, sarcastic comments a bit tiring and dull.  I'm not sure how many times I am going to hear, "I am with the Las Vegas crime lab," or how many times the show features a suspect who is being shown overwhelming evidence of their guilt, and backs down, and reveals their guilt.  I think the show is starting to get dull.  I have learned a lot of science from the show, but I will not watch another one.
summary: The first few seasons were good, but this one is a bit dull.

reviewText: I didn't believe the first few seasons could be improved upon but the fourth is equally good, with even more wild and interesting plot twists. The creative juices that flow from the writers is something I'd like to see bottled. How do they manage, week after week, to present fine acting, fine plots, fine characters and fine editing and sound? And Petersen and Co. are not exactly hard to look at, either. It's a joy to sit down to watch these episodes.However, I suggest resisting the temptation to watch several at once for fear of running out and getting withdrawal symptoms. We are down to our last few episodes and will mourn the day we watch the last one -- at least until the 5th season comes out on DVD.

reviewText: It's amazing that a prime time network drama, let alone the highest rated program on television today, can still maintain the freshness that made it so popular.  The fourth season of C.S.I. found the series rejuvinated along with it's main protagonist, Gil Grissom (William Petersen, sporting his Manhunter-era beard), who has since regained his hearing, and is once again at the top of his game.  During the season, Gil has a choice ahead of him on who to promote, whether it be Nick (George Eads) or Sara (the gorgeous Jorja Fox), while the rest of the C.S.I. members personal lives take a back seat for some of the most elaborately portrayed crimes ever seen on network TV, and the twists and turns made as they are solved.  C.S.I. really came back into it's own during the fourth season, once again becoming a force to be reckoned with as new characters are introduced, and the season comes to a bit of a shocker of a close.  The episode entitled "Fur and Loathing" will go down in C.S.I. history as one the most infamous episodes of the series that you have to see to believe.  All in all, C.S.I. still continues to roll along as the best show on network TV, and if you are one of the few who has never watched this addictive show, you do not know what you're missing.

reviewText: A great show with a great cast.  The Las Vegas Crime Lab are the characters on this show, backed up here and there by the LVPD.The third season ended with Gil Grissom (the main character) going in for ear surgery.  He had been losing his hearing for some time, his mother had went deaf, and he would too if he didn't get this operation.  On the first episode on this set, Grissom lets his co-worker Catherine know that her cell phone is vibrating.  She says, "You can hear that?  You're back."Also on the first episode of this set, the character Nick Stokes tells a guy, who he knew long ago - who recognizes him now, about some specifics on the case they're working on.  We find out that guy leaked the info to the press - which creates a problem between Grissom and Nick.Another problem in the storylines is concerning the character Sara Sidel, who shows early on in this set, that she's mad at Grissom.  Late in season three, she asked him out - and he said 'no'.So aside from all the personal drama between the characters, the murder cases themselves are always interesting.One of things that people love about this show (and its spin-offs) are 'The CSI Shot':  an extreme close-up used in every episode.  This close-up shot is used to help us (the viewer) see better what they (the investigators and coroners) are seeing.  The camera zooms in on and through gunshot wounds; through blood streams; wounds to the back of the head; anything useful.On the final episode of this box set, aside from a drunk driving accident involving one of the characters, the boss Gil Grissom promises to the lab tech character Greg that he will be put 'in the field', like the other CSI criminalists.  This fact is true:  as in season five (the newest season, airing this fall) a new lab tech enters the show, and Greg is given field work.  Greg, due to his good sense of humor, has got to be my favorite character on the show.So check out season four, and the others one too, if you haven't already.  Don't let that $75-$80 pricetag on this set scare you, you won't be disappointed.The first season of CSI:  Miami is also on DVD, the second season will be out later this year, with the third season airing on TV.  The Miami show I really didn't enjoy too much, I think because of the cast.  Also this fall, CSI:  New York starts its first season.  Gary Sinice is the star of that one, who has studied up on forensic science in the past - for his villian character on the movie "Ransom"
summary: One of the Best Shows in a While
